SENT.plain: Recent studies have shown a good response to immunosuppressive treatment with cyclosporin A (CSA) in patients with the myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)
We have treated six transfusion-dependent MDS patients with CSA for a minimum of 3 months
None of these patients showed a significant response, while the drug was withdrawn in 3/6 patients because of intolerable side-effects
Two reasons for the failure of this treatment in our patients can be advanced
Firstly, the hypoplastic variant of MDS predominated in previous studies in contrast to ours
Secondly, the concomitant use of other immunosuppressive agents in previous studies might have enhanced the effect of CSA

We suggest further therapeutic trials of CSA in MDS, selecting patients on the basis of in vitro studies that predict an immunological basis for their disease, to assess its efficacy in prolonging survival
